President Trump's executive order banning certain people from traveling to the United States was poorly planned, poorly executed and fundamentally wrong.   In addition to the administration's claim that "only" 109 people were detained at various US airports, there are hundreds that were turned away before getting on a flight, thousands scheduled to come in the next few days, and 67,000 refugees that have already been vetted and approved after a 2 year process rife with delay and bureaucracy.  I can only imagine the fear, the suffering and instability.  There is much more work to be done!  I am traveling to Washington DC now.  I am one of the original co-sponsors of a Congresswoman Grace Meng's bill to defunded the president's ability to enforce the executive order.  I'm on a conference call with legal experts from many not for profit organizations to discuss different legal and legislative strategies.  I am joining Democratic Senators and Congress members on the steps of the Supreme Court at 6pm tonight to demand that the president rescind his order.  Please advise me of any personal stories of people in my district effected by this misguided effort by the president.  Thank you. We are all concerned about our safety, but this will not make us safer and may have the opposite effect.  Keep pushing!

Bipartisan Tour of Guantanamo Military Base in Cuba.   We left the Capitol at 5am this morning, flew on a military plane to Guantanamo, and received a tour of the detention facilities. The  41 detainees include, among others, the masterminds behind the 9/11 and USS Cole terrorist attacks - these murderers include Khalid Sheikh Mohammed.   GTMO has held over 700 detainees since 9/11 and now holds 41. 7 of these enemy combatants are now engaged in a lengthy military tribunal process, are represented by counsel (which the United States funds millions per year on their behalf) and are treated in accordance with the Geneva Convention. 3 detainees have already been convicted and the remainder continue to be detained under the "laws of war."  This is a serious and costly operation with no easy answers. This issue poses many public policy questions, but it is apparent why President Obama was unable to completely close the facility.  Americans don't want detainees in their back yards. The military tribunals must be held in facilities that can handle top secret information due  to its sensitive classified nature that may be disclosed during the trial process. The process may take many more years due to the legal wrangling. Some of the detainees are an incredibly high security risk. Yet, some including former General Petraeus, believe the facility should be closed because it serves as a great propaganda and recruiting tool for our enemies. We do hold other terrorists in America that have been convicted already.   I am heading back to the Capitol for votes tonight, but I would like to know what do you think?  God Bless our men and women in uniform and God Bless the United States of America.

Afghanistan, Kuwait, UAE and Jordan - Part 4  Below is a video from last Monday soon after we arrived in Southern Afghanistan at Train Advise and Assist - South in Kandahar for a briefing and to meet the troops. Train, Advise and Assist is the US mission to enable the Afghanistan (and other) military to defeat these enemies. "By, with and through" their efforts we will defeat these criminals/terrorists.  There is a cap on the number of US personnel. We are below 10,000 whereas years ago we were over 100,000.  Challenges remain:     1) Corruption in the Afghan Forces which the Afghani government with our assistance is making some positive headway,     2) Tribalism, where some groups are more loyal to their local tribe than to their nation. This is a work in progress as the Afghans try and build a nation and a sense of nationalism.      3) the terrorists/criminals fund their operations as the largest grower of poppy (used to make heroin) in the world. The heroin in America does not come from Afghanistan, but 80% of Canada's supply comes from here, as does Iran's (Iran should wake up to their own self interest and help destroy these poppy fields).    4) the border with Pakistan is ungoverned and porous. Terrorists roam freely from Pakistan in to Afghanistan regularly. Pakistan's military must do a better job helping out. (In a later post I will discuss Nangdahar Province where the MOAB was dropped to help fortify the border and defeat ISIS).  Our military is on an important and often misunderstood mission. I am so impressed by their intelligence, courage and the responsible way in which they are conducting their mission. They need our help, support and understanding.  There are enemies/criminals/terrorists who will take a generation to defeat. We must enlist and enable other local populations who we will,  "by, with and through" their efforts, defeat this scourge on humankind.  The answers will not come through killing the enemy as the only strategy, but it is an essential piece. I will discuss this more in future posts.

Afghanistan, Kuwait, UAE and Jordan - Part 8  Our last day in Afghanistan we met with the United States Ambassador Hugo Llorens and his team in Kabul, we went to TAAC-East at Camp Gamberi near Jalalabad and focused heavily on Nangdahar Province (where the MOAB was dropped the next day) and the Pakistan border generally, We later met with General John Nicholson (4 stars), who Commands the Resolute Support Mission in Kabul, before heading to Bagram. We flew overnight from Bagram to Kuwait on a C-130 (not much sleep).  Ambassador Llorens and his team and General Nicholson and his team both gave excellent accounts of what has happened in Afghanistan over the past 15 years and the plan moving ahead as well as the political dynamic with President Ghani and Chief Executive Abdullah.  There is a clear 4 year plan to further empower the Afghani Army, Air Force, Special Forces and Police, and to persuade Pakistan to take a more positive role. The plan on the civil side is less defined. I think there needs to be a commensurate 4 year plan regarding infrastructure, energy, education and economic development.  The border with Pakistan must be secured and the terrorist/criminal forces in previously "forbidden forests" (my phrase) must be routed out (hence the MOAB). Additionally there must be a plan to disrupt the poppy refinement into heroin that is the major source of income for these criminals.  The next morning we were in Kuwait to meet regarding the Iraq and Syria conflicts.

Afghanistan, Kuwait, UAE and Jordan - Part 9  Kuwait  Arrived in the middle of the night at Ahmed Al Jaber Air Base. The photo of the bombed out concrete hanger below is a remnant of Saddam Hussein's Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in the early '90's. Kuwait remains an excellent ally, that like the UAE and Jordan, are reliable friends that encourage US presence and serve as bases to access the entire region - especially Iraq and Syria.  We first met with Marine command that focuses on, among other things, the Tactical Recovery of Aircraft and Personnel. We toured the Osprey (with helicopter and fixed wing airplane capability) that are used for those operations. We met with the commander's innovation team which is utilizing 3D printers in the field to create tools and spare parts in theatre (impressive) and had lunch with soldiers from Long Island and discussed some of the challenges they face.  We then moved by van to Camp Arifjan for some intense briefings from Army Central Command, the Combined Joint Task Force - Operation Inherent Resolve and Special Operations regarding the strategy and operations in Iraq and Syria. (Sorry, no pictures).  Tremendous progress is being made in Iraq "by, with and through" the Iraqis. Our military has a well thought out plan for the Iraqi's to retake Mosul, which will deliver a major blow to the ISIS caliphate in Iraq.  Syria is incredibly complex with 7 major players in addition to the terrorists/criminals 1) Assad, 2) the Russians, 3) the Iranians, 4) the revolutionaries, 5) the Kurds, 6) the Turks (who don't trust the Kurds), and 7) the US.  Arguably, as the US, and our allies help defeat ISIS, we are helping Assad, Russia and Iran who also oppose ISIS. The goal is to retake Raqqah which is the hub of the ISIS caliphate in Syria. We should be looking for something in return from Iran and Russia as we help accomplish their mutual goal in defeating ISIS.  I supported the Syrian Air Base strike in response to Assad's use of chemical weapons, but the time has come for the president to layout a long term plan that seeks bipartisan support for congress.  We also met with the US Ambassador to Kuwait Larry Silverman and Kuwaiti officials to discuss the region.  1) we cannot relent on ISIS, AQ and any other terrorist/criminal organization that seeks to export their violence to the west and our land,  2) we should ramp up our "by, with and through" strategy that empowers local governments to police their own lands (we do not want to be an occupying force - we can't afford it from a human or monetary perspective and it will not work).  3) we should bring together Muslim allies like Kuwait, Jordan, the UAE and others from the region, as well as Muslims from Indonesia, Malaysia and elsewhere who oppose the criminals/terrorists to present the true picture of Islam and their opposition to our common enemies.  4) we must have a commensurate, long term civil response that encourages economic development, education and cooperation with our Muslim friends that empowers them to overcome the criminals.

Afghanistan, Kuwait, UAE and Jordan - Part 10  UAE - we arrived early in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates and met with Embassy officials and received classified briefings regarding Yemen and the region in general. Unlike portrayals in movies and on TV, I find that our military and special forces execute their duties carefully, responsibly and with close attention to their legal authority.   Later at Al Dafra Air Force Base it became apparent how close a relationship we enjoy with the UAE. The facilities and proposed upgrades are a good indication of what a great ally they are.  The Air Force has 5 missions and Al Dafra has aircraft needed to help fulfill each mission in the entire region 1) Air and Space Superiority, 2) intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance, 3) Rapid Global Mobility, 4) Global Strike and 5) Command and Control. Afghanistan, Kuwait, UAE and Jordan - Part 12 - Final  This is my last post regarding the bipartisan CODEL to this region. Below are pictures of the Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi, and our meeting with the US Ambassador there. We did not have the time to go inside or do any touristy type stops. Our final stop in Jordan (one of our closest allies) was equally informative, but I never had the chance to take any photos with the Ambassador or military personnel. Jordan remains central to our US strategy in the Middle East. It shares borders with Syria, Iraq, Israel and Saudia Arabia. It has enormous pressure from the 1.3 million Syrian refugees who now call it home. It's central location, 150,000 troops, long and trusted relationship and role in Jerusalem make Jordan one of our most important allies.  7 final points:  1) I have always supported our troops, but I have new and deeper admiration for our military men and women. The intelligence, courage and responsible way they execute their duties is sobering, humbling and inspiring. I am so impressed by the leadership cadre and the scores that fill the ranks. God bless them, guide them and keep them safe.  2) I have always tried to stay informed, but I have a new understanding of the complexity of our involvement in this region. Yet I have a deep appreciation of the merit and simplicity of America's "by, with and through" strategy that seeks to empower local forces, and de-risk our personnel, while shouldering our burden to defeat the existential threat of the criminals/terrorists that would do us and the world order harm.  3) we must protect our diplomatic corps and their funding. President Trump's proposed cuts to the State Department are reckless, uninformed and irresponsible. Our diplomatic personnel are also intelligent, courageous and responsible in the execution of their duties and they are equally responsible for our long term success.  4) killing our enemies is sadly a necessary part of our strategy, but it can never be the final answer to our generational threat we face from the criminals/terrorists that are manically set upon killing and intimidating us. We must also help our friends and allies build the competence to  protect themselves and provide a sustainable quality of life for their people.  5) we must help those in the 1.5 billion of the Muslim world who join with us in the condemnation of the criminal/terrorist adulteration of Islam to stand together in solidarity against this existential scourge.  6) politicians need to put aside the petty political games and recognize the serious import of the jobs we have. We must work together to solve problems and get things done.  7) I am so grateful for the opportunity to serve.

Tonight the president is scheduled to finally reveal his plan for Afghanistan. While he may be trying to divert attention from his recent controversies, America's strategy for Afghanistan under this administration is past due and must be disclosed.  Here is what I am hoping the president says tonight. "Based upon consultation with military and diplomatic experts in my administration, I believe we must increase the number of troops engaged in the "Train, Advise and Assist" mission in Afghanistan by 3,000."  Below is a more detailed explanation of my position.  I traveled to Afghanistan this spring and reported on it extensively on this page.  I have discussed with the US Commander in Afghanistan, General Nicholson, his proposed strategy during my trip. In my capacity as a member of the House Armed Services and Foreign Affairs Committees, I have met with and questioned Secretary of Defense Mattis and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Dunford on this same topic. I have spoken with numerous other military officials in both Afghanistan and here in the US on this topic. I have also discussed this issue with diplomats in the State Department and intelligence officials.  Several points are important to make clear:  1) At least a dozen of the over 60 terrorist organizations in the world operate out of Afghanistan.  2) We have remained in Afghanistan for over 15 years because we cannot allow the terrorist organizations operating there to have any respite. They will use Afghanistan for training and for planning further coordinated attacks in Europe and the US.  3) We have drawn down the number of US troops from a peak of over 100,000 to about 8,500 troops today.  4) The primary US mission is to train, advise and assist the Afghan Army so that they may take the fight to the enemy and "by, with and through them" the enemy will be defeated.  5) There is currently a 5-point plan in Afghanistan; i) train, advise and assist the Afghan army, ii) train, advise and assist the Afghan Special Forces, iii) train, advise and assist the Afghan Air Force and help build it to effectively coordinate with the Army, iv) help train the local police force, and v) get Pakistan to a better job securing its borders and going after terrorists that operate within Pakistan and ply the porous borders between the two countries. This plan should continue.  6) The US needs a commensurate Civil/State Department driven plan and any plan for Afghanistan must consider the entire region, especially, but not limited to Pakistan and Iran.  Every expert I have spoken with has made a persuasive case that 1) we cannot leave Afghanistan, 2) we should maintain our Train, Assist and Advise/By, With and Through Strategy, 3) Afghanistan's government is making progress rooting out corruption (but still has a long way to go) and promoting a sense of nationalism over tribalism, and 4) we must put more pressure on Pakistan to cooperate.  More specifically, the purpose of increasing the number of troops is to provide "force protection" to our own existing troops. We need troops, not to further engage the enemy - which is now limited to our special forces and our troops only when they are engaged by the enemy - but to protect our Armed Services when they are deployed to Train, Advise and Assist the Afghanis. These additional troops would also be used to replace expensive private contractors that are currently used to protect our bases in Afghanistan.   It is everyone's natural inclination, including mine, to say "this has gone on much too long, let's bring our troops home," and "we have spent too much blood and treasure already on the ungovernable part of the world."  However, I believe the sad reality is that we are in a long term battle in a changed world and until Afghanistan can govern itself (which must be the goal), we must do everything we can to help disrupt these terrorist organizations so they cannot organize and attempt to harm Americans or our friends in Europe and Eastern Europe. The long term solution cannot be to simply kill our enemies, but we must in the meanwhile prevent them from purveying their sinister hate, anarchy and criminality throughout the world. This increase, of what I hope will be about 3,000 troops, is unfortunately a necessary part of achieving our long term goals and restoring order.

The biggest problem in America today is partisan division. Partisanship is caused because over 400 of the 435 seats in The House of Representatives are "safe" seats.  If you are a Republican in a Republican safe seat or a Democrat in a Democratic safe seat, you can't lose the general election. You can only lose a primary.   Few people vote in primaries (often under 10% of the registered voters in each party) and the few that do vote are often far to the right for Republicans and far to the left for Democrats. So incumbents in safe seats spend a great deal of effort pleasing the base of their party faithful that vote in primaries.  It gets very difficult to compromise if you are set on only pleasing your base.  The only way to solve this problem is to have less safe seats. The only way to have less safe seats is to get rid of partisan gerrymandering. One of the only ways to get rid of partisan gerrymandering is to have the Supreme Court declare it unconstitutional.  I am one of 36 members and former members of Congress (half Dems and half Reps) that have signed on to a "friend of the Court) brief to be argued before the Supreme Court on Tuesday.  Stay tuned!  https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/09/29/opinion/gerrymandering-supreme-court.html   https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/09/29/opinion/gerrymandering-supreme-court.html
